title: Getting started with the tumr package
code: library(tumr) data("melanoma2") plot_mean <- function(data, group, time, measure, id, stat = median, remove_na = FALSE){   data_summary <- data |>     dplyr::group_by({{group}}, {{time}}) |>     dplyr::summarise(measure = stat({{measure}}, na.rm = remove_na), .groups = "drop_last") |>     dplyr::ungroup()    if (remove_na == TRUE){     data_full <- data |>       na.omit(data)   } else {     data_full <- data   }    ggplot2::ggplot() +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_full,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = {{measure}},                                     group = {{id}},                                     color = {{group}}),                        alpha = 0.5)  +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_summary,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = measure,                                     color = {{group}}),                        linewidth = 1.2)  }

title: Getting started with the tumr package
code: plot_mean <- function(data, group, time, measure, id, stat = median, remove_na = FALSE){   data_summary <- data |>     dplyr::group_by({{group}}, {{time}}) |>     dplyr::summarise(measure = stat({{measure}}, na.rm = remove_na), .groups = "drop_last") |>     dplyr::ungroup()    if (remove_na == TRUE){     data_full <- data |>       na.omit(data)   } else {     data_full <- data   }    ggplot2::ggplot() +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_full,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = {{measure}},                                     group = {{id}},                                     color = {{group}}),                        alpha = 0.5)  +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_summary,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = measure,                                     color = {{group}}),                        linewidth = 1.2)  }

what: Plotting the Mean vs the Median
title: Getting started with the tumr package
code: mel2 <- tumr(melanoma2, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment) plot_mean(melanoma2, Treatment, Day, Volume, ID, stat = mean) mel2 |>   plot_median()

title: Authors and Citation
text: Patrick Breheny. Author, maintainer. Sydney Plowman. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Breheny P, Plowman S (2025). tumr: Analysis Power Calculations Tumor Growth Rates. R package version 0.5.1, https://pbreheny.github.io/tumr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tumr: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates},   author = {Patrick Breheny and Sydney Plowman},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.5.1},   url = {https://pbreheny.github.io/tumr/}, }

what: Tumor growth data for a breast cancer model — breast
title: Tumor growth data for a breast cancer model — breast
text: strain rat, tumors begin appear 6 weeks carcinogen followed another 6 weeks. goal study estimate effects nicotinamide riboside (dietary supplement) growth mammary gland tumors.

title: Tumor growth data for a breast cancer model — breast
Tumor growth data for a breast cancer model — breast
text: data frame 336 rows 6 variables: ID Mouse identifier indicate repeated measurements mouse. (factor) Cohort Indicator cohort mouse belonged , order account potential batch effects. (factor) Treatment Treatment group (factor). VEH = control (vehicle), NR = nicotinamide riboside Week Week measurment (integer) Volume Tumor volume, cubic mm (double) Number Number tumors (integer)

title: Tumor growth data for a breast cancer model — breast
text: University Iowa, Holden Cancer Center, experiment PJB17-025.

what: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
text: Generate tumor data: Time reach endpoint

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
text: n Number mice per group effect_size Vector effect sizes, growth ratio (default: 2) m Number measurements per mouse (default: 3) alpha Shape parameter gamma distribution (default: 9) sd Noise (standard deviation, default: 100)

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
text: Y            Observed measurements M            Idealized 'true' size mouse time (error) B            'True' growth rate mouse (data-generating mechanism)

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
code: Data <- gendat(5, effect_size=2, m=6) matplot(Data$time, t(Data$Y[,,1]), lty=1, type='l', col='#FF4E37', bty='n', las=1,         ylab=expression("Tumor volume "*(mm^3)), xlab='Day') matplot(Data$time, t(Data$Y[,,2]), lty=1, type='l', col='#008DFF', add=TRUE)

title: Linear Mixed Model for Tumor Growth Data — lmm

title: Linear Mixed Model for Tumor Growth Data — lmm
code: lmm(   tumr_obj = NULL,   formula = NULL,   data = NULL,   id = NULL,   time = NULL,   measure = NULL,   group = NULL,   ... )

title: Linear Mixed Model for Tumor Growth Data — lmm
text: tumr_obj takes tumr_obj created tumr() formula linear mixed model formula data tumor growth data id Column subject ID's time Column repeated time measurements measure Column repeated measurements tumor group Column specifying treatment group measurement ... arguments lme4::lmer()

title: Linear Mixed Model for Tumor Growth Data — lmm

code: data(melanoma1) mel1 <- tumr(melanoma1, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment) plot_median( tumr_obj = mel1 )  data(melanoma2) plot_median( data = melanoma2, group = "Treatment", time = "Day", measure = "Volume", id = "ID" )  data(prostate) plot_median( data = prostate, group = "Genotype", time = "Age", measure = "BLI", id = "ID" )

what: Tumor growth data for a prostate cancer model — prostate
title: Tumor growth data for a prostate cancer model — prostate
text: experiment, 49 mice split 3 groups. groups Pten, cancer gene, knocked prostates. One group normal p53, one group one copy p53 knocked , third group copies p53 knocked prostates. mice also bioluminescent reporter tumor progression monitored imaging.

title: Tumor growth data for a prostate cancer model — prostate
Tumor growth data for a prostate cancer model — prostate
text: data frame 336 rows 6 variables: ID Mouse identifier indicate repeated measurements mouse. (factor) Age Age mouse, weeks (integer) BLI Tumor volume, measured bioluminescent imaging, photons (double) Genotype p53 genotype (factor). WT = wild type, HET = single knockout, DOKO = double knockout.

title: Tumor growth data for a prostate cancer model — prostate

title: Analysis based on response features — rfeat
code: data(breast) rfeat( data = breast, id = "ID", time = "Week", measure = "Volume", group = "Treatment", transformation = log1p, comparison = "t.test") #>  #> 	Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  Beta by Group #> t = 0.64605, df = 24.351, p-value = 0.5243 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group NR and group VEH is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.3345751  0.6398147 #> sample estimates: #>  mean in group NR mean in group VEH  #>         0.8872739         0.7346541  #>  data(melanoma1) rfeat( data = melanoma1, id = "ID", time = "Day", measure = "Volume", group = "Treatment", comparison = "anova") #>             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> Group        3   4645  1548.3   35.62 3.64e-10 *** #> Residuals   31   1347    43.5                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

title: Creates a summary of an lmm object — summary.lmm
code: mel1 <- tumr(melanoma1, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment) mel1_lmm <- lmm(mel1) #> Warning: Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.3043 (tol = 0.002, component 1) summary(mel1_lmm) #> Cannot use mode = "kenward-roger" because *pbkrtest* package is not installed #> Cannot use mode = "kenward-roger" because *pbkrtest* package is not installed #> $`overall effect of time` #>  1       Day.trend      SE   df lower.CL upper.CL #>  overall    0.0324 0.00466 39.4    0.023   0.0418 #>  #> Results are averaged over the levels of: Treatment  #> Degrees-of-freedom method: satterthwaite  #> Confidence level used: 0.95  #>  #> $`slope of treatment over time` #>  Treatment Day.trend      SE   df lower.CL upper.CL #>  A            0.0642 0.01010 58.0  0.04388 0.084443 #>  B            0.0217 0.00822 26.7  0.00485 0.038618 #>  C            0.0611 0.01020 53.0  0.04077 0.081522 #>  D           -0.0174 0.00860 25.3 -0.03508 0.000318 #>  #> Degrees-of-freedom method: satterthwaite  #> Confidence level used: 0.95  #>  #> $`test slope differences` #>  contrast estimate     SE   df t.ratio p.value #>  A - B     0.04243 0.0130 41.2   3.252  0.0118 #>  A - C     0.00302 0.0143 55.5   0.210  0.9967 #>  A - D     0.08154 0.0133 39.4   6.136  <.0001 #>  B - C    -0.03941 0.0131 39.4  -3.015  0.0223 #>  B - D     0.03911 0.0119 25.9   3.287  0.0145 #>  C - D     0.07852 0.0133 37.8   5.899  <.0001 #>  #> Degrees-of-freedom method: satterthwaite  #> P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 4 estimates  #>
